Grandma’s bananas 
 Ursula Nafula 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Grandma’s garden was wonderful - ful of
 sorghum, milet, and casava. But best of
 
 al were the bananas. 
 
 Although Grandma had many 
 
 grandchildren, I secretly knew that I was
 her favourite. She invited me often to her
 house. She also told me litle secrets.
 
 
 But there was one secret she did not
 
 share with me: where she ripened
 bananas. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day I saw a big straw basket placed 
 in the sun outside Grandma’s house. 
 
 When I asked what it was for, the only 
 answer I got was, “It’s my magic basket.” 
 
 
 Next to the basket, there were several 
 banana leaves that Grandma turned from 
 time to time. 
 
 
 I was curious. “What are the leaves for, 
 
 Grandma?” I asked. The only answer I 
 got was, “They are my magic leaves.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was so interesting watching Grandma,
 the bananas, the banana leaves and the
 
 big straw basket. But Grandma sent me
 of to my mother on an erand. 
 
 
 “Grandma, please, let me watch as you
 prepare…” 
 
 “Don’t be stuborn, child, do as you are
 told,” she insisted. I tok of runing.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When I returned, Grandma was siting 
 
 outside but with neither the basket nor 
 the bananas. 
 
 
 “Grandma, where is the basket, where are 
 al the bananas, and where…” 
 
 
 But the only answer I got was, “They are 
 in my magic place.” 
 
 It was so disapointing! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Two days later, Grandma sent me to
 
 fetch her walking stick from her
 bedrom. 
 
 
 As son as I opened the dor, I was
 welcomed by the strong smel of ripening
 bananas. In the iner rom was 
 
 grandma’s big magic straw basket. It was
 wel hiden by an old blanket. I lifted it
 
 and snifed that glorious smel.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Grandma’s voice startled me when she
 
 caled, “What are you doing? Hury up
 and bring me the stick.” 
 
 
 I huried out with her walking stick.
 
 
 “What are you smiling about?” Grandma
 asked. 
 
 Her question made me realise that I was
 stil smiling at the discovery of her magic
 place. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The folowing day when grandma came 
 to visit my mother, I rushed to her house 
 
 to check the bananas once more. 
 
 There was a bunch of very ripe ones. I 
 
 picked one and hid it in my dres. After 
 covering the basket again, I went behind 
 
 the house and quickly ate it. It was the 
 swetest banana I had ever tasted. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The folowing day, when grandma was in
 
 the garden picking vegetables, I sneaked
 in and pered at the bananas. 
 
 
 Nearly al were ripe. I couldn’t help taking
 a bunch of four. 
 
 
 As I tiptoed towards the dor, I heard
 
 grandma coughing outside. I just
 managed to hide the bananas under my
 dres and walked past her. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The folowing day was market day. 
 
 Grandma woke up early. She always tok 
 ripe bananas and casava to sel at the 
 market. 
 
 
 I did not hury to visit her that day. But I 
 
 could not avoid her for long. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Later that evening I was caled by my
 mother and father, and Grandma. I knew
 why. 
 
 
 That night as I lay down to slep, I knew I
 could never steal again, not from
 
 grandma, not from my parents, and
 certainly not from anyone else.
